questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Concrete is a mixture of cement, water, and aggregate (usually sand or gravel). The cement and water react chemically to form a hard paste, which binds the aggregate together.

The strength of a cylindrical sample of concrete is measured by subjecting the sample to increasing vertical compression until it breaks (see Figure 1). The vertical compression needed to break the sample is, called the compressive strength and is measured in kg/cm2.


An engineer conducted the following studies to determine factors that affect the compressive strength of concrete.

Study 1
Eight groups of cylindrical concrete samples were prepared—4 using Type I cement (Groups A-D) and 4 using Type II cement (Groups W-Z). All samples had the same dimensions. The water content, by weight, was the same in each sample but the cement content, by weight, was varied to create different water to cement ratios in each group. Each sample contained the same type and amount of aggregate. After the samples had been aged (allowed to sit undisturbed) under identical conditions for 28 days, their compressive strengths were measured. The results are shown in Table 1.


Study 2
Cylindrical concrete samples were prepared as in Study I using Type II cement. Groups of samples with varying water:cement ratios were aged under identical conditions for 1, 3, 7, or 28 days and were then tested for compressive strength. The results are shown in Figure 2.


Figure adapted from Steven Kosmatka and William Panarese, Design and Control of Concrete Mixtures. ©1979 by the Portland Cement Association.
questions.question: 1.  Plans for a new building show that the supporting pillars would be subject to a maximum vertical compression of 350 kg/cm2. According to Study 1, the pillars should be made from concrete like that in Sample Groups:

choices.B: B and C.
choices.C: B and Z.
choices.D: C and D.

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:

questions.question: 2. Based on the results of Study 1, the compressive strength of Type II cement concrete with a water:cement ratio of 4:10 and aged 28 days would most likely be:

choices.B: between 265 kg/cm2 and 330 kg/cm2.
choices.C: between 330 kg/cm2 and 400 kg/cm2.
choices.D: greater than 400 kg/cm2.

questions.question: 3.  According to the results of Study 1, for any given water:cement ratio, the compressive strength of concrete made with Type I cement is approximately:

choices.A: one-half that of concrete made with Type II cement.
choices.B: the same as that of concrete made with Type II cement.
choices.C: twice that of concrete made with Type II cement.
choices.D: three times that of concrete made with Type II cement.

questions.question: 6.  For concrete with a given water:cement ratio, which of the following statements describing the relationship between aging period and the compressive strength of concrete is best supported by the results of Study 2? The compressive strength of concrete:

choices.A: increases as the length of the aging period increases.
choices.B: decreases as the length of the aging period increases.
choices.C: remains the same as the length of the aging period increases.
choices.D: increases, then decreases as the length of the aging period increases.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
The shape of a planet's orbit around a star is elliptical. Kepler's third law of motion relates the planet's orbital period (the time the planet takes to complete one orbit) to the ellipse's semimajor axis, a, (see Figure 1) and the star's mass. Figure 2 contains a graph of the orbital period versus a for 6 of the planets that orbit the Sun. The average orbital speeds of these planets are plotted versus a in Figure 3.

Kepler's third law also describes a moon's orbit around a planet. Figure 4 contains graphs of the orbital period versus a for moons orbiting hypothetical planets of various masses.


(Note: In Figures 2-4, 1 AU = 1.5 x 108 km, the average distance from Earth to the Sun, and periods are given in multiples of Earth days or years.)




(Note: In Figure 4, moons' masses are assumed to be insignificant compared to the masses of planets they orbit.)
questions.question: 7.  According to Figure 2, as the semimajor axis of a planet's orbit increases, the orbital period of the planet:

choices.B: decreases.
choices.C: changes, but with no clear trend.
choices.D: remains constant.

questions.question: 11.  The planets in Figure 3, ranked from smallest to largest according to their masses, are Mercury, Mars, Venus, Earth, Saturn, and Jupiter. Does this information and Figure 3 support the hypothesis that a planet's mass and its orbital speed are related?

choices.A: Yes, because as planetary mass increases, planetary orbital speed increases.
choices.B: Yes, because as planetary mass increases, planetary orbital speed decreases.
choices.C: No, because as planetary mass increases, planetary orbital speed decreases.
choices.D: No, because as planetary mass increases, planetary orbital speed changes with no clear trend.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article: An electrochemical cell (Figure 1) is constructed with an anode, a strip of zinc (Zn) placed in a solution of zinc ions (Zn2+), and a cathode, a strip of copper (Cu) or silver (Ag) placed in a solution of copper ions (Cu2+) or silver ions (Ag1+) , respectively. The solutions are connected by a salt bridge (a tube filled with a solution containing nitrate ions). The anode and cathode are connected to a voltmeter. Tables 1 and 2 show how the mass (g) of the anode or cathode, concentrations (M) of the ionic solutions, and temperature (°C), affect the voltage difference(V) between Zn and either Cu or Ag.
questions.question: 12.  Which of the following variables was NOT altered in the measurements of Cells 6-9?

choices.B: Concentration of Zn2+
choices.C: Temperature
choices.D: Mass of the cathode

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Researchers performed the following experiments to evaluate the effectiveness of a disinfectant (chemical) called NoGrow (NG) at stopping bacterial growth.

Experiment 1
Equal amounts of a solution containing the bacterium Escherichia coli (E. coli) were added to 5 test tubes. One sample was not exposed to NG; the remaining 4 samples were exposed to 0.1 mL of NG for different times. The 5 samples were then washed to remove the NG and incubated for 24 hours at 37°C. After the 24-hour period, researchers checked the samples for bacterial growth (see Table 1).


Experiment 2
Experiment 1 was repeated with the bacterium Staphylococcus epidermidis (S. epidermidis). The results appear in Table 2.


Experiment 3
Experiment 1 was repeated with the bacterium Bacillus subtilis (B. subtilis). The results appear in Table 3.


Experiment 4
Four test tubes containing equal amounts of S. epidermidis and 1.0 mL of sterile water were subjected to different temperatures. Samples from each tube were taken periodically. Then the samples were washed, incubated, and checked for bacterial growth as described above. The results appear in Table 4.


Experiment 5
The same procedure described in Experiment 4 was used with 4 tubes containing S. epidermidis and 0.1 mL of NG. The results appear in Table 5.
questions.question: 17.  Which of the following aspects of the experimental design used in Experiment 1 is NOT explained in the passage?

choices.A: How the samples were checked for bacterial growth
choices.B: How much NG was contained in each tube
choices.C: How long the tubes were incubated
choices.D: How many samples were used

questions.question: 18.  Based on the results of Experiment 4, if a researcher wants to treat test tubes so that the growth of S. epidermidis will be prevented, the researcher should subject the glassware to which of the following sets of conditions?

choices.B: 60℃ water for 10 min
choices.C: 60℃ water for 15 min
choices.D: 100℃ water for 5 min

questions.question: 20.  The results of Experiments 1, 2, and 3 are most consistent with the conclusion that for the 3 bacteria tested, NG is:

choices.A: least effective at stopping the growth of E.coli.
choices.B: least effective at stopping the growth of S. epidermidis.
choices.C: most effective at stopping the growth of E. coli.
choices.D: most effective at stopping the growth of S. epidermidis.

choices.A: temperature at which the experiment is performed.

questions.question: 22.  Is the conclusion that “E. coli does not grow well after heating at 100℃" supported by the results of Experiment 4?

choices.A: No; after 2.5 min of exposure, bacterial growth occurred.
choices.B: No; E.coli was not used in Experiment 4.
choices.C: Yes; after 5.0 min of exposure, bacterial growth was stopped.
choices.D: Yes; E.coli growth is stopped by NG.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Nemoria caterpillars that hatch in the spring mature into a yellow, ridged morph (body type); those that hatch in the summer mature into a gray, smooth morph. A researcher hypothesized that caterpillar morphology is influenced by 3 environmental factors: temperature, photoperiod (hours [hr] of sunlight per day), and diet. He performed 3 studies on Nemoria.

Study 1
Treatment groups (groups exposed to different experimental conditions) of equal numbers were created by varying 3 factors: temperature (15°C or 25°C), photoperiod (12.5 hr or 14 hr), and diet (catkins [oak flower clusters] or oak leaves). The percent of caterpillars that developed into each morph appears in Table 1.


Study 2
Caterpillars were raised at 25°C, with a 14 hr photo-period, and on 1 of 5 diets: catkins, catkins and oak leaves, catkins and tannins (a compound found in oak leaves, but not found in catkins), oak leaves, or oak leaves without tannins. The percent that developed into each morph appears in Table 2.


Study 3
Female caterpillars were raised at 25°C with a 14 hr photoperiod on either catkins or oak leaves. Pupation time in days (d), pupal weight (g),and number of offspring produced by female moths were recorded (see Figure 1).



Tables and figure adapted from Erick Greene, "A Diet-Induced Developmental Polymorphism in a Caterpillar." ©1989 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
questions.question: 23.  Based on the results of Study 1, if a researcher wanted to produce yellow-morph Nemoria caterpillars, there searcher should:

choices.B: feed the caterpillars oak leaves only.
choices.C: expose the caterpillars to a 14 hr photoperiod.
choices.D: expose the caterpillars to a 12.5 hr photoperiod.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Nemoria caterpillars that hatch in the spring mature into a yellow, ridged morph (body type); those that hatch in the summer mature into a gray, smooth morph. A researcher hypothesized that caterpillar morphology is influenced by 3 environmental factors: temperature, photoperiod (hours [hr] of sunlight per day), and diet. He performed 3 studies on Nemoria.

Study 1
Treatment groups (groups exposed to different experimental conditions) of equal numbers were created by varying 3 factors: temperature (15°C or 25°C), photoperiod (12.5 hr or 14 hr), and diet (catkins [oak flower clusters] or oak leaves). The percent of caterpillars that developed into each morph appears in Table 1.


Study 2
Caterpillars were raised at 25°C, with a 14 hr photo-period, and on 1 of 5 diets: catkins, catkins and oak leaves, catkins and tannins (a compound found in oak leaves, but not found in catkins), oak leaves, or oak leaves without tannins. The percent that developed into each morph appears in Table 2.


Study 3
Female caterpillars were raised at 25°C with a 14 hr photoperiod on either catkins or oak leaves. Pupation time in days (d), pupal weight (g),and number of offspring produced by female moths were recorded (see Figure 1).



Tables and figure adapted from Erick Greene, "A Diet-Induced Developmental Polymorphism in a Caterpillar." ©1989 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
questions.question: 24.  The experimental procedures used in Studies 1 and 2 differed in that, in Study 2, some caterpillars were:

choices.B: fed both catkins and oak leaves.
choices.C: raised with a 14 hr photoperiod.
choices.D: raised at a temperature of 25°C.

questions.question: 25.  Which of the following sets of conditions best characterizes a treatment group used in Study 1?

choices.A: A temperature of 14°C, a photoperiod of 12.5 hr.and a diet of oak leaves
choices.B: A temperature of 14°C, a photoperiod of 15 hr, and a diet of catkins
choices.C: A temperature of 25°C, a photoperiod of 12.5 hr, and a dict of oak leaves
choices.D: A temperature of 25°C, a photoperiod of 15 hr, and a dict of catkins

questions.question: 26.  A student raised a female Nemoria caterpillar at 25℃ with a 14 hr photoperiod and a diet composed entirely of catkins. Based on the results of Study 3, the caterpillar would most likely have a pupation time of approximately how many days?

questions.question: 27.  Which of the following generalizations about pupation times and pupal weights in female Nemoria  caterpillars is consistent with the results of Study 3? Compared to caterpillars fed a diet of oak leaves, caterpillars fed a diet of catkins tend to have:

choices.A: longer pupation times and higher pupal weights.
choices.B: longer pupation times and lower pupal weights.
choices.C: shorter pupation times and higher pupal weights.
choices.D: shorter pupation times and lower pupal weights.

questions.question: 28.  A student hypothesized that Nemoria caterpillars feed primarily on catkins during the summer. Do the results of Study 1 support this hypothesis, and why?

choices.A: Yes; summer caterpillars are yellow, indicating that they are feeding primarily on catkins.
choices.B: Yes; summer caterpillars are gray, indicating that they are feeding primarily on catkins.
choices.C: No; summer caterpillars are yellow, indicating that they are feeding primarily on oak leaves.
choices.D: No; summer caterpillars are gray, indicating that they are feeding primarily on oak leaves.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Earth's interior is divided into 4 primary layers of different chemical composition: the crust, mantle, outer core, and inner core. Figure 1 shows the 4 layers, their depths, and 2 named layer boundaries (Moho and Gutenberg Discontinuity). The lithosphere, asthenosphere, and transition zone boundaries were determined using speed changes in S waves, a type of earthquake wave. Speed changes indicate a phase and/or density change of material inside Earth.


Figure 2 shows how P-wave (another earthquake wave type) and S-wave velocities and density change with depth inside Earth.


Figure 3 shows how Earth's temperature changes with depth.
questions.question: 29.  A drilling project on one of the continents struck the Moho at a depth of 60 km below the surface and a similar project on an ocean struck that boundary at a depth of 10 km beneath the ocean floor. Based on these facts and the information provided, which of the following statements about layer thickness is most accurate?

choices.A: The crust is thinner under the continents.
choices.B: The crust is thinner under an ocean.
choices.C: The lithosphere is thicker than the lower mantle.
choices.D: The mantle is thinner under an ocean.

questions.question: 30.  S waves do not travel through liquids. Based on this fact and the data provided, which of Earth's layers is most likely completely liquid?

choices.B: Mantle
choices.C: Asthenosphere
choices.D: Outer core

choices.A: The lithosphere includes the crust and part of the mantle.
choices.B: The lithosphere transmits only S waves.

choices.D: The lithosphere is thicker than the transition zone.

choices.A: Pressure is highest in the mantle.
choices.B: Pressure is highest in the outer core.
choices.C: Pressure is highest in the inner core.
choices.D: Pressure is constant throughout Earth's interior.

questions.question: 33.  According to the data provided, what is the relationship between S-wave velocity and density in the mantle?

choices.A: As density increases, S-wave velocity increases.
choices.B: As density increases, S-wave velocity decreases.
choices.C: As density increases, S-wave velocity remains the same.
choices.D: As density increases, S-wave velocity increases, then decreases.

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
A double-stranded DNA molecule is shown in Figure 1. Each single strand, or polynucleotide, is composed of repeating subunits called nucleotides. A nucleotide is composed of a sugar, a phosphate group, and a base. There are 4 types of bases in DNA: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine.

Nucleotides are joined in a ladderlike structure. The sugars and phosphate groups form the sides of the ladder, or backbones, while pairs of bases form the rungs. Pairing between bases is specific:adenine alway bind with thymine, and guanine always binds with cytosine. Basepairs are connected together with hydrogen bonds, weak chemical bonds.


Scientists have proposed 3 models to explain how DNA replicates.

Semiconservative Model
DNA is separated into 2 polynucleotides by breaking the bonds between the base pairs. Each parental polynucleotide serves as a template for the synthesis of a new polynucleotide. Each parental polynucleotide then combines with the new polynucleotide synthesized from it. Thus, after replication, each DNA molecule is composed of a parental polynucleotide and a new polynucleotide（Figure 2).


Conservative Model
DNA is separated into 2 polynucleotides by breaking the bonds between the base pairs. Each polynucleotide serves as a template for the synthesis of a new polynucleotide. The parental polynucleotides then rejoin; the new polynucleotides also combine. Thus, after replication, 1 DNA molecule is composed of parental DNA; the other is composed of new DNA (Figure 3).


Dispersive Model
DNA is separated into 2 polynucleotides by breaking the bonds between the base pairs. Each polynucleotide is then fragmented along the length of the sugar-phosphate backbone into many short, single-stranded polynucleotide fragments. Each fragment serves as a template for the synthesis of a new complementary fragment. The fragments then combine so that, after replication, each DNA molecule contains many pieces of parental DNA and many pieces of new DNA (Figure 4).
questions.question: 34.  According to the passage, polynucleotides are composed of:

choices.B: phosphate groups and bases only.
choices.C: sugars and bases only.
choices.D: sugars, phosphate groups, and bases.

questions.question: 35.  All 3 models assert that which of the following must occur before new polynucleotides are synthesized?

choices.B: Base pairs must be separated.
choices.C: DNA backbones must be fragmented.
choices.D: DNA bases must be converted into sugars.

questions.question: 37.  A problem in DNA replication that is unique to the Conservative Model is how the:

choices.A: bonds between the sugars and phosphate groups are broken prior to replication.
choices.B: cell obtains the chemical components necessary for replication.
choices.C: parental polynucleotides recognize each other and rejoin after replication.
choices.D: double-stranded parental DNA is used as a template without being separated into single polynucleotides.

questions.question: 38.  All 3 models assert that when 2 polynucleotides com-bine to form 1 double-stranded DNA molecule, bonds form between which DNA components?

choices.A: The sugars of one polynucleotide and the sugars of the other polynucleotide
choices.B: The bases of one polynucleotide and the bases of the other polynucleotide
choices.C: The phosphate groups of one polynucleotide and the sugars of the other polynucleotide
choices.D: The phosphate groups of one polynucleotide and the bases of the other polynucleotide

choices.B: parental polynucleotides are fragmented during replication.
choices.C: new polynucleotides contain the same bases as the parental polynucleotides.
choices.D: new polynucleotides can act as a template for additional rounds of replication.

questions.question: 40.  A drug that blocks the synthesis and accumulation of adenine and guanine would prevent a cell from replicating its DNA according to which model (s) of DNA replication?

choices.B: The Semiconservative and Conservative Models only
choices.C: The Conservative and Dispersive Models only
choices.D: The Semiconservative, Conservative, and Dispersive Models
